replies.comment info:
HI, @Dahlia N.R. --

You bring up an important point about how the data was collected.  You are asking about the methodology of the survey.  Conclusions based on statistics are only as good as how they were generated. There is a lengthy explanation in the full report (stateofnation.org).  In general, the findings are from surveys previously undertaken, which use different methodologies.  

You can also read in the full report about what the committee members thought were the reasons for the changes in rank.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Kasey AOSE --

Thank you for your thoughtful noticings.  

Quite a few students misinterpreted the meaning of the crossover points in the graphs between the start date and the ending date.  These are slope graphs that have only two data points -- the beginning and the ending.  The line just shows whether the variable (rank) is increasing, decreasing or staying the same, ergo slope graph.  That is why, for  example, there are only two dates on the x-axis.  

To read how the scholars interpreted the data, do to the report athttps://stateofnation.org/.

comment info:
Thanks to all the students who responded.   Here are some of the catchy headlines we received:  “We Aren't Happy and We're Dying Young ... But at Least We're Working Hard!” by Sienna and Olivia of Tenakill Middle School in Closter, N.J., "Shifting Prosperity: U.S. Faces Declining Satisfaction Amidst Economic Gains" by Lily at Academy of Saint Elizabeth, Convent Station, N.J. and three headlines from Perth Amboy High School, N.J. –“Money Buys Happiness? U.S. Prosperity and Global Quality of Life” by Lavon, “Big Bucks, Small Smiles: What's Going On, USA?” by Johan and "Rich in GDP, Poor in Spirit: America’s Happiness in Deficit?" by Daniel.

Please return on Friday when we will reveal the free link to the article, a summary of the article, additional questions, shout outs for some of the best headlines for the graph and Stat Nuggets -- definitions of words that relate to the graph and where you can find them in the graph.

The next graph will be released by Friday, April 11.  The topic is how we’ve changed since Covid.

Signing off – Sharon Hessney from Boston who is mindful about the wealth gap that causes, in part, the unhappiness, and Kristina Barnaby of Fairfield, Conn., who fights social isolation by taking long walks with her family and dog.

name: Giulia AOSE
comment info:
Headline- Trouble in Paradise

What I notice:
Seven different graphs highlight the United States specifically in categories that measure prosperity and quality of life. I noticed that in total GDP, the U.S. held the #1 spot in 1990, but by 2023 it had slipped to #2. Surprisingly, the U.S. only ranks 10th in productivity. Despite being such a wealthy country, the U.S. has seen a drop in both life satisfaction and life expectancy, which is quite concerning. Trust in the federal government has also plummeted, as well as social isolation. The only steady metric is the average years of education. 

What I wonder:
Why did the U.S. drop so much in life satisfaction, life expectancy, and trust in the federal government, all in a matter of a couple of years? Could this be a product of the extreme political polarization or the economy? Also, what’s holding back productivity in such a wealthy nation? Why is social isolation also still so low? Did COVID affect these results a lot?

How does this relate to me and my community?
This relates to me and my community because I live in the U.S., and I see people working hard every day, like my parents, but they are still stressed. People I know deal with so many health issues or feel unhappy; that doesn't seem to happen in other countries. Now, more than ever, many don’t trust the government and are extremely skeptical. Although our economy may seem fine, people are generally unhappy in the country.

replies.comment info:
HI, @Priscilla Lee --

This is a slope graph which displays a starting and ending data point, but none in between.  The slope of the time displays the change over the entire period.
  
Think about it – is it likely that any of these metrics would change at a constant rate or vary from year to year?  It’s more likely that they would change from year to year in different ways for each metric.  These year-by-year data points would be displayed on a time series graph.

Why do you think the journalist used a slope graph rather than a time series graph?

comment info:
Observations - The US maintains a high GDP ranking. Its productivity metric has been steadily rising since 2005, but its social and wellbeing metrics, like life satisfaction and trust in the government, are all declining. It shows how economic strength doesn’t necessarily equate to the overall health of a society. 

Questions - Is increased productivity coming at the expense of individual wellbeing? Is there a correlation between economic growth and the decline in social satisfaction? Additionally, how much does the political climate affect the trust in the federal government?

Relation to Community - Living in NJ, these trends are concerning. It is imperative to think about the pressures we face in our daily lives and whether our focus on economic success is overshadowing our quality of life. People are struggling with the feeling of disconnection and a lack of faith in our institutions.

Headline - "Rich in GDP, Poor in Spirit: America’s Happiness in Deficit?"

name: Johan P3
comment info:
1)These charts show how the U.S. ranks among high-income countries over time in several key areas. While the U.S. maintains its top rank in total GDP from 1990 to 2023, it falls behind in several quality-of-life indicators. Life expectancy drops from 19th to 29th, and trust in the federal government plunges from 20th to 34th. The U.S. also becomes more socially isolated, slipping from 2nd to 10th, while its average years of education ranking remains steady at 4th. Despite high productivity and wealth, the decline in well-being metrics suggests broader societal challenges.
2)I also wonder how these rankings would look if broken down by region within the U.S., since national averages might mask significant internal differences in health, education, and social well-being
3)Living in New Jersey, I definitely see some of these trends play out around me. There's a lot of talk and frustration about the government, and it feels like trust in federal leadership has really dropped over the years. On the upside, with industries like pharma, finance, and tech doing well here, I’ve seen how the U.S.’s strong economy and productivity can translate into job opportunities.
4)Big Bucks, Small Smiles: What's Going On, USA?

replies.name: L
replies.comment info: @Johan P3 You make a great point about how national averages can hide regional differences in things like health, education, and social well-being. Your experience in New Jersey really brings this to light—despite strong industries like pharma, finance, and tech offering job opportunities, there’s still a lot of frustration with the government and a sense of distrust. It’s interesting how economic success doesn’t always translate to improved social connections or well-being.
